p: In temperate climates, respiratory CoV infections occur more often in the winter and spring than in the summer and fall. CoV infections have shown to contribute as much as 35% of the total respiratory viral activity during epidemics. The predominant illness associated with CoVs is an upper respiratory infection with occasional cases of pneumonia in infants and young adults [ 1, 4]. CoVs have also been shown to be effective in producing asthma exacerbations in children, as well as chronic bronchitis in adults and the elderly [ 5]. The milder forms caused by the four strains (OC43, NL63, HKU1, and 229E) of CoVs are found globally and are responsible about one-fifth of common colds or flu without leaving permanent immunity [ 4].
